member.name: M:ProcessHacker.Native.Api.Win32.NtCreateProfile(System.IntPtr@,System.IntPtr,System.IntPtr,System.IntPtr,System.Int32,System.IntPtr,System.Int32,ProcessHacker.Native.Api.KProfileSource,System.IntPtr)
member.summary: Creates a profile object.
member.param: A handle to the profile object.
A handle to the process to profile. If NULL, all address spaces are profiled.
The first address at which to collect profiling information.
The size of the range to profile. ProfileBase <= address < ProfileBase + ProfileSize will generate a hit.
A log2 value of each address bucket. Acceptable values are from 2 to 30.
An array of int hit counters.
The size of the buffer, in bytes.
The profiling source.
The processors to profile.

member.name: M:ProcessHacker.Native.Api.Win32.NdfCancelIncident(System.IntPtr)
member.summary: The NdfCancelIncident function is used to cancel unneeded functions which have been previously called on an existing incident.
member.remarks: Before using this API, an application must call an incident creation function such as NdfCreateWebIncident. NdfCloseIncident should be used to close an incident once it has been resolved, as NdfCancelIncident does not actually close the incident itself.
member.param: A handle to the Network Diagnostics Framework incident. This handle should match the handle of an existing incident.
member.returns: A HResult value indicating the result

member.name: M:ProcessHacker.Native.Api.Win32.NdfCloseIncident(System.IntPtr)
member.summary: The NdfCloseIncident function is used to close an Network Diagnostics Framework (NDF) incident following its resolution.
member.param: The handle to the NDF incident that is being closed.
member.returns: A HResult value indicating the result

member.name: M:ProcessHacker.Native.Api.Win32.NdfCreateConnectivityIncident(System.IntPtr@)
member.summary: The NdfCreateConnectivityIncident function diagnoses generic internet connectivity problems.
member.param: The handle to the Network Diagnostics Framework incident.
member.returns: A HResult value indicating the result

member.name: M:ProcessHacker.Native.Api.Win32.NdfCreateInboundIncident(System.String,System.String,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.IntPtr@)
member.summary: The NdfCreateInboundIncident function creates a session to diagnose inbound connectivity for a specific application or service.
member.param: The fully qualified path to the application receiving the inbound traffic.
The Windows service receiving the inbound traffic.
The SID for the application receiving the traffic. If NULL, the caller's SID is automatically used.
A SOCKADDR_STORAGE structure which limits the diagnosis to traffic to a specific IP address. If NULL, all traffic will be included in the diagnosis
The protocol which should be diagnosed. For example, IPPROTO_TCP would be used to indicate the TCP/IP protocol.
The Inbound flags for specifying the type of options to preform during diagnostics.
Pointer to a handle to the Network Diagnostics Framework incident.
member.returns: A HResult value indicating the result

member.name: M:ProcessHacker.Native.Api.Win32.NdfCreateDNSIncident(System.String,System.UInt16,System.IntPtr@)
member.summary: The NdfCreateDNSIncident function diagnoses name resolution issues in resolving a specific host name.
member.param: The host name with which there is a name resolution issue.
The numeric representation of the type of record that was queried when the issue occurred.
A handle to the Network Diagnostics Framework incident.
member.returns: A HResult value indicating the result

member.name: M:ProcessHacker.Native.Api.Win32.NdfCreateSharingIncident(System.String,System.IntPtr@)
member.summary: The NdfCreateSharingIncident function diagnoses network problems in accessing a specific network share.
member.param: The full UNC string (for example, "\\server\folder\file.ext")for the shared asset with which there is a connectivity issue.
A handle to the Network Diagnostics Framework incident.
member.returns: A HResult value indicating the result

member.name: M:ProcessHacker.Native.Api.Win32.NdfCreateWebIncident(System.String,System.IntPtr@)
member.summary: The NdfCreateWebIncident function diagnoses web connectivity problems concerning a specific URL.
member.param: The URL with which there is a connectivity issue.
A handle to the Network Diagnostics Framework incident.
member.returns: A HResult value indicating the result

member.name: M:ProcessHacker.Native.Api.Win32.NdfCreateWebIncidentEx(System.String,System.Boolean,System.String,System.IntPtr@)
member.summary: The NdfCreateWebIncidentEx function diagnoses web connectivity problems concerning a specific URL. This function allows for more control over the underlying diagnosis than the NdfCreateWebIncident function.
member.param: The URL with which there is a connectivity issue.
If TRUE, diagnosis is performed using the WinHTTP APIs. Otherwise, the WinInet APIs are used.

The module name to use when checking against application-specific filtering rules (for example, "C:\Program Files\Internet Explorer\iexplorer.exe"). If NULL, the value is autodetected during the diagnosis.
A handle to the Network Diagnostics Framework incident.
member.returns: A HResult value indicating the result

member.name: M:ProcessHacker.Native.Api.Win32.NdfExecuteDiagnosis(System.IntPtr,System.IntPtr)
member.summary: The NdfExecuteDiagnosis function is used to diagnose the root cause of the incident that has occurred.
member.param: A handle to the Network Diagnostics Framework incident.
The handle to the window that is intended to display the diagnostic information. If specified, the NDF UI is modal to the window. If NULL, the UI is non-modal.
member.returns: A HResult value indicating the result

member.name: M:ProcessHacker.Native.Api.Win32.NdfGetTraceFile(System.IntPtr,System.String)
member.summary: The NdfGetTraceFile function is used to retrieve the path containing an Event Trace Log (ETL) file that contains Event Tracing for Windows (ETW) events from a diagnostic session.
member.param: A handle to a Network Diagnostics Framework incident. This handle should match the handle of an existing incident.
Pointer to a string that contains the location of the trace file.
member.returns: A HResult value indicating the result

member.name: M:ProcessHacker.Native.Api.Win32.EnumServicesStatusEx(System.IntPtr,System.IntPtr,ProcessHacker.Native.Api.ServiceQueryType,ProcessHacker.Native.Api.ServiceQueryState,System.IntPtr,System.Int32,System.Int32@,System.Int32@,System.Int32@,System.String)
member.summary: Enumerates services in the specified service control manager database. The name and status of each service are provided, along with additional data based on the specified information level.
member.param: A handle to the service control manager database.
Set this to 0.
The type of services to be enumerated.
The state of the services to be enumerated.
A pointer to the buffer that receives the status information.
The size of the buffer pointed to by the Services parameter, in bytes.
A pointer to a variable that receives the number of bytes needed to return the remaining service entries, if the buffer is too small.
A pointer to a variable that receives the number of service entries returned.
A pointer to a variable that, on input, specifies the starting point of enumeration. You must set this value to zero the first time the EnumServicesStatusEx function is called.
Must be 0 for this definition.
member.returns: A non-zero value for success, zero for failure.

member.name: F:ProcessHacker.Native.Api.ImageBaseRelocationType.Absolute
member.summary: The base relocation is skipped. This type can be used to pad a block.

member.name: F:ProcessHacker.Native.Api.ImageBaseRelocationType.High
member.summary: The base relocation adds the high 16 bits of the difference to the 16-bit field at offset. The 16-bit field represents the high value of a 32-bit word.

member.name: F:ProcessHacker.Native.Api.ImageBaseRelocationType.Low
member.summary: The base relocation adds the low 16 bits of the difference to the 16-bit field at offset. The 16-bit field represents the low half of a 32-bit word.

member.name: F:ProcessHacker.Native.Api.ImageBaseRelocationType.HighLow
member.summary: The base relocation applies all 32 bits of the difference to the 32-bit field at offset.

member.name: F:ProcessHacker.Native.Api.ImageBaseRelocationType.HighAdj
member.summary: The base relocation adds the high 16 bits of the difference to the 16-bit field at offset. The 16-bit field represents the high value of a 32-bit word. The low 16 bits of the 32-bit value are stored in the 16-bit word that follows this base relocation. This means that this base relocation occupies two slots.

member.name: F:ProcessHacker.Native.Api.ImageBaseRelocationType.MipsJmpAddr
member.summary: The base relocation applies to a MIPS jump instruction.

member.name: F:ProcessHacker.Native.Api.ImageBaseRelocationType.MipsJmpAddr16
member.summary: The base relocation applies to a MIPS16 jump instruction.

member.name: F:ProcessHacker.Native.Api.ImageBaseRelocationType.Dir16
member.summary: The base relocation applies the difference to the 64-bit field at offset.

member.name: F:ProcessHacker.Native.Api.ImageCharacteristics.RelocsStripped
member.summary: Image only, Windows CE, and Windows NTÂ® and later. This indicates that the file does not contain base relocations and must therefore be loaded at its preferred base address. If the base address is not available, the loader reports an error. The default behavior of the linker is to strip base relocations from executable (EXE) files.

member.name: F:ProcessHacker.Native.Api.ImageCharacteristics.ExecutableImage
member.summary: Image only. This indicates that the image file is valid and can be run. If this flag is not set, it indicates a linker error.

member.name: F:ProcessHacker.Native.Api.ImageCharacteristics.LineNumsStripped
member.summary: COFF line numbers have been removed. This flag is deprecated and should be zero.

member.name: F:ProcessHacker.Native.Api.ImageCharacteristics.LocalSymsStripped
member.summary: COFF symbol table entries for local symbols have been removed. This flag is deprecated and should be zero.

member.name: F:ProcessHacker.Native.Api.ImageCharacteristics.AggressiveWsTrim
member.summary: Obsolete. Aggressively trim working set. This flag is deprecated for Windows 2000 and later and must be zero.

member.name: F:ProcessHacker.Native.Api.ImageCharacteristics.LargeAddressAware
member.summary: Application can handle > 2 GB addresses.

member.name: F:ProcessHacker.Native.Api.ImageCharacteristics.Reserved
member.summary: This flag is reserved for future use.

member.name: F:ProcessHacker.Native.Api.ImageCharacteristics.BytesReversedLo
member.summary: Little endian: the least significant bit (LSB) precedes the most significant bit (MSB) in memory. This flag is deprecated and should be zero.

member.name: F:ProcessHacker.Native.Api.ImageCharacteristics.ThirtyTwoBitMachine
member.summary: Machine is based on a 32-bit-word architecture.

member.name: F:ProcessHacker.Native.Api.ImageCharacteristics.DebugStripped
member.summary: Debugging information is removed from the image file.

member.name: F:ProcessHacker.Native.Api.ImageCharacteristics.RemovableRunFromSwap
member.summary: If the image is on removable media, fully load it and copy it to the swap file.

member.name: F:ProcessHacker.Native.Api.ImageCharacteristics.NetRunFromSwap
member.summary: If the image is on network media, fully load it and copy it to the swap file.

member.name: F:ProcessHacker.Native.Api.ImageCharacteristics.System
member.summary: The image file is a system file, not a user program.

member.name: F:ProcessHacker.Native.Api.ImageCharacteristics.DLL
member.summary: The image file is a dynamic-link library (DLL). Such files are considered executable files for almost all purposes, although they cannot be directly run.

member.name: F:ProcessHacker.Native.Api.ImageCharacteristics.UPSystemOnly
member.summary: The file should be run only on a uniprocessor machine.

member.name: F:ProcessHacker.Native.Api.ImageCharacteristics.BytesReversedHi
member.summary: Big endian: the MSB precedes the LSB in memory. This flag is deprecated and should be zero.

member.name: T:ProcessHacker.Native.Objects.ProcessHandle
member.summary: Represents a handle to a Windows process.
member.remarks: The idea of a ProcessHandle class is different to the class; instead of opening the process with the right permissions every time a query or set function is called, this lets the users control when they want to open handles with certain permissions. This means that handles can be cached (by the users).
